af38e7b6-40c0-4571-bacf-e109a2d3a62b.description: The collaboration of Dakota Geriatrics, National Indian Council on Aging, The University of North Dakota Center for Rural Health and Quality Health Associates of North Dakota presents 1st Annual Symposium on Age Friendly Care in the Great Plains to be held on March 30th -31st , 2021 via zoom webinar.
af38e7b6-40c0-4571-bacf-e109a2d3a62b.name: Age-Friendly Healthcare Champion

issuer.summary: issued by University of North Dakota

badge_template_activities.title: Geriatric problems are common but often under recognized in health care. Over 80% of older adults with memory impairment go unrecognized by their primary care providers. Nearly two thirds of older adults at risk for falls have no mitigating health care plan. To address this gap, Age Friendly Healthcare adopts evidence-based practice through the Geriatric 4Ms: What Matters, Mentation, Medication and Mobility.

A 2-half day symposium sponsored by Dakota Geriatrics will bring regional experts to discuss the Geriatric 4Ms in patient care specific for American Indian populations in the Great Plains. Day 1 (March 30th 2021) will address health care issues confronting older adults and community workers (3 social worker contact hours provided) and Day 2 (March 31st 2021) will focus on how providers and healthcare professionals can better assess and manage the older adult patient.
Participants can receive up to 5 free educational credits.

In additional to education credits, attendees can earn the UND sponsored Digital Badge by fulfilling 3 tasks: 1. 100% attendance on day 2 sessions 2. Completion of all pre and post assessments 3. Complete the program evaluation form post event.

badge_template_activities.title: The badge earner participated in a 90-minute workshop on Universal Design for Learning.

The badge earner learned how to move from focusing on the word “accessibility” to focusing their efforts on expanding "access," regardless of the ability profiles of their learners, and they learned how to shift their goals away from making content accessible and instead looking at making interactions easier to engage in.

The badge earner learned that they need to beyond the mental model of universal design (UD) in the physical environment, which is static, bounded, and predictable – instead designing interactions according to UDL, which see interactions as dynamic, open, and emergent.
The badge earner learned manageable starting points for student-supported universal design.

1. BEFORE THE INTERVIEW 1.1. Understanding the opportunity 1.2. Understanding the topic 1.3. Identifying talking points 1.4. Background Materials 1.5. Delivering Your Message 1.6. Questions in Advance 1.7. Appearance

alignments.name: Ethical Standards for Clinical Documentation (1 hour of Ethics CE)
alignments.description: Understand and state what the role of the CDM, CFPP is in healthcare documentation.

alignments.description: Define medical and clinical documentation and state the differences between the two.

alignments.name: Ethical Standards for Clinical Documentation (1 hour of Ethics CE)
alignments.description: Define and then compare/contrast these terms: ethics, morals, and law.

alignments.description: Compare and contrast the terms privacy and confidentiality.

alignments.description: State the purpose and need for documentation as it relates to patient-centered care.

alignments.description: State and understanding the pivotal role of documentation in portraying quality of care, the legal and professional responsibilities, and how inaccuracies may discredit the care of the provider.

alignments.name: Nutrition Care – The Power of the Pen…Communication in Charting (35 hours of General CE)
alignments.description: Discuss the way that patient data is stored in the electronic medical record (EMR).

alignments.name: Nutrition Care – The Power of the Pen…Communication in Charting (35 hours of General CE)
alignments.description: Discuss the role of the CDM, CFPP in documentation, and how the ANFP supports the documentation with confidentiality practices, professional practice standards, continuing education, professional competencies, and the scope of practice.

alignments.name: Nutrition Care – The Power of the Pen…Communication in Charting (35 hours of General CE)
alignments.description: Utilize the general principles needed to effectively communicate in the EMR.

alignments.description: Utilize and practice screening, assisting the RD in assessing, planning, implementing, and evaluation techniques to provide good flow in your documentation of patient care, as defined by the Scope of Practice for the CDM, CFPP.

alignments.name: Nutrition Care – The Power of the Pen…Communication in Charting (35 hours of General CE)
alignments.description: Discuss and utilize basic documentation principles and standards for good documentation which include clear, concise, and comprehensive communication.

alignments.name: Nutrition Care – The Power of the Pen…Communication in Charting (35 hours of General CE)
alignments.description: Assist in the planning of patient interventions, critical thinking leading directly into setting the plan of care and using SOAP notes and SMART objectives to document your patient/client’s progress.

alignments.description: Discuss how facility owns the “chart” but the client owns the information written about them.

alignments.description: Understand and use the concept of 'person-centered' care and how that is the main driver in providing care in the healthcare setting.

alignments.description: See how person-centered care provides a base for showing respect to each individual person and how this connects to all parts of the IDT and the puts the person at the center of care.

alignments.name: Nutrition Care – The Power of the Pen…Communication in Charting (35 hours of General CE)
alignments.description: Understand and utilize the interdisciplinary plan of care to drive quality and personalized care, which advances each discipline high standards of caregiving.

alignments.name: Nutrition Care – The Power of the Pen…Communication in Charting (35 hours of General CE)
alignments.description: Understand the importance of clinical documentation as evidence of patient care. Failure to document care means that there was a failure to provide care.

ed630a43-cd96-424a-b164-9d17c9ffb8e9.description: COVID-19 has highlighted some of the realities students face in managing technology, be it a digital divide with disparity in access to technology and/or internet access, or constraints around space, from experiencing poverty or homelessness to living in multi-generational households. In this session, the badge earner will learn about factors that influence students learning in this virtual environment and learn about Zoom features that can enhance and humanize the classroom experience.

8599e1ec-b523-4f47-8bd0-052c93e39a88.description: Intersections is a series of workshops to increase understandings of intersectionality, an affirmation of the roles multiple identities have in relationship to our social lives and interconnected systems of power, privilege, and oppression. Sessions include facilitated conversations, individual activities, and presentations that look at lived experiences through multiple dimensions of race, gender, sexuality, socioeconomic status, and more.
8599e1ec-b523-4f47-8bd0-052c93e39a88.name: Intersectionality Awareness

issuer.summary: issued by University of North Dakota

badge_template_activities.title: The badge earner will learn how the purpose of Intersections is to dive deeper into understanding how people different from you experience the social world.

The badge earner will gain awareness and understanding of the following topics to apply in their future social interactions, careers, and lived experiences. • Ableism and disability • Anti-racism and white consciousness • Intro to intersectionality • Intersectional Feminism • Queer and Trans Identities • Religion and Spirituality • Unpacking Identity • Unseen Biases

5a8f46e7-609e-40ca-ba67-3869fce2fa13.description: The main focus is to educate people about the invisibility that Native Americans face that often goes unnoticed by the public. We educate people about Native Americans and their cultures to lessen the perpetuation of stereotypes, racist ideas, and targeted violence.
5a8f46e7-609e-40ca-ba67-3869fce2fa13.name: Invisible No More: Learning About Indigenous Culture

issuer.summary: issued by University of North Dakota

badge_template_activities.title: Participants will identify Indigenous cultural values and beliefs which may differ from their own.
Participants will identify not knowing about Indigenous culture and will become more comfortable with engaging in conversation with Indigenous individuals.
Be able to make connections between an Indigenous lesson story and one’s own life experiences.
Be aware of the rate of targeted violence against Indigenous people.

bf38b752-ea13-4a68-ae6b-fba64bd1391d.description: For the SMHS medical program class of 2026 and beyond (mandatory): A point system is used to classify interprofessional activities across all phases. These points are aligned across three different levels to earn badges for Interprofessional Collaboration. Phase 1 students must earn 8 points to achieve the Competency level. Phase 2/3 students must earn an additional 2 points for a total of 10 points. Please refer to the criteria for specific information regarding how to earn points.
bf38b752-ea13-4a68-ae6b-fba64bd1391d.name: SMHS Medical Program Interprofessional Collaboration (Level 1: Competency)

badge_template_activities.title: Earn 3 points by completing the Interprofessional Health Care course (IPHC).
Earn 2 points by completing the ROBOTS teleheath simulation.
Earn 1 point by completing the nursing (drug allergy) simulation.
Earn 1 point by completing the PharmD (drug overdose) simulation.
Earn 1 point by completing the PharmD/MD "match day" activity.

Required for Phase 2/3 students only: Earn 2 points by selecting optional IPE/C activities provided by the Office of Interprofessional Education, or by documenting one of the many IPE/C interactions that occur formally or informally during Clinical Education. Please note that similar 1-2 point activities may only be used a maximum of 3 times.
